title: 110_hr634
content: The "American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes the sacrifices of disabled veterans and aims to mint a commemorative silver dollar coin in their honor. Congress acknowledges the service and sacrifices of veterans from various wars and emphasizes the importance of honoring those who have served and those who have made the ultimate sacrifice for their country. The American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act proposes minting a commemorative silver dollar coin to honor living disabled veterans. The coin would raise funds for the construction of the American Veterans Disabled for Life Memorial. The coin specifications include a weight of 26.73 grams, a diameter of 1.500 inches, and a composition of 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins minted would be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins is also outlined in the Act. The American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act proposes minting a commemorative silver dollar coin to honor living disabled veterans. The design of the coins shall symbolize the service of disabled veterans who defended democracy. The coins will have inscriptions of value, year, and patriotic words. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations. The coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a designated mint facility. The American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act specifies that coins honoring disabled veterans will be minted in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated mint facility in West Point, New York. The Secretary can only issue these coins during the calendar year starting on January 1, 2010. The sale price of the coins includes the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders are accepted. The Secretary will make bulk sales of coins at a discount and accept prepaid orders before issuance. All coin sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin, with proceeds going to the Disabled Veterans' LIFE Memorial Foundation for the construction of the American Veterans' Disabled for Life Memorial in Washington, D.C. The Comptroller General has the right to audit the Foundation's expenditures. The surcharge for coin issuance under this Act is limited to avoid exceeding the annual commemorative coin program issuance limitation. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide guidance for this limitation.
